webelements.content: 3D-DERMS: Data-Driven Distribution Systems Distributed Energy Resource Management System

A distributed energy resource management system (DERMS) is a software platform used to manage a group of distributed energy resources (DERs), such as solar PVs, behind-the-meter battery energy storage, demand response or a fleet of electric vehicles (EVs) as well as distributed wind, to deliver vital grid services and balance demand with supply to help utilities achieve mission-critical outcomes. An effective and reliable DERMS could allow the high penetration of DERs integrations while improving grid resiliency, reliability and economic. In existing DERMS, the coordination of various DERs is achieved via some optimization models, where accurate feeder model and sufficient sensor data are required. The optimization model is difficult to solve due to the nonlinear power flow constraints and the lack of load information across the whole network at every time step. However, in practical distribution system operation, the DER controllers do not have the real-time load information for all nodes and the secondary feeder models are of very low quality. There are also works based on the design of autonomous volt-var/watt control but the system-wide coordination is lacking, and thus they do not guarantee the satisfaction of system-level optimality. For utilities without DERMS or advanced distribution management systems, advanced control/optimization algorithms to integrate DERs securely and reliably are needed.

This project will develop a novel data enhanced DERMS that is scalable, modular, and flexible, allowing utilities to meet current needs, and grow as circumstances dictate, such as dealing with increasing load and energy storage installations. This novel data driven DERMS solution shown in the right figure is achieved by developing a new voltage sensitivity enabled feedback optimization framework that allows the coordinated control of any types of DERs. Grid measurements from smart meters and DERs are gathered and provided to the optimization algorithm. With data-driven sensitivity index, the optimization model is formulated as a linear programming problem to diminish computational complexity and hence enable a measurement-feedback online scheme. The proposed solution does not need the load knowledge across the feeder and can be implemented online thanks to fast solver for linear programing problem. This DERMS online platform is generalizable to deal with various types of DERs including PVs, energy storage, EVs, distributed wind, demand response, etc.

3D-DERMS supports many different types of business cases to host utilities, including enhancing system resiliency and reliability, peak load shifting, system losses minimization, reduce DER curtailments, Volt-VAR optimization, voltage profiles and power factor improvement, management of congestion and circuit overloads that defers capital expenditures, supplying ancillary and other grid services to bulk power and electricity markets.
